Graphical abstract The review mainly introduces three methods of wettability control in electrocatalyst: morphology control, surface coating and functional group which cover multiple electrocatalytic fields such as OER, HER, ORR and CO2RR. Electrocatalysis, as a typical heterogeneous catalysis, generally occurs in the di- or tri-phase interfaces. Wettability is an important property for describing the balance of a gas-liquid-solid system. Therefore, the wettability of reaction interface, especially hydrophilicity/hydrophobicity, plays an important role in the adsorption/desorption process of gas bubbles on the surface of the solid electrode. Herein, we present a comprehensive review of the wettability control of the electrode materials applied in electrocatalysis reactions, including hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen evolution reaction (OER), oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR). Firstly, the basic theories of wettability as well as the impact on electrocatalysis were introduced in this review. Secondly, the overview of modifying methods of the wettability from electrocatalyst microstructure (structural modification, surface coating, introducing hydrophilic groups) and system design (electrode, device) were suggested. At last, the deficiencies and problems in the application of wettability control are discussed, and deeper and broader application prospects are proposed. Keywords Electrocatalysis Reaction interfaces Wettability Gas evolution reactions Gas consumption reactions 1 Introduction The shortage of fossil fuel and the deterioration of ecological environment push human to vigorously develop renewable energy generation technology [1–6]. However, the intermittent nature seriously limits the practical applications of renewable energy [7]. Electrocatalysis, one of the new energy storage and conversion technologies, can solve this problem by transferring renewable energy to chemical energy, and then releasing chemical energy to produce continuous power [8,9]. To achieve a high efficiency of this energy conversion process, nowadays, numerous researches modify the electronic configuration of electrocatalysts to promote the intrinsic activity by tuning components [10], controlling morphology [11], designing crystalline structures [12], etc. Equally important, achieving fast kinetics of mass and electric transfer on the electrode is the basic principle to release the intrinsic activity of electrocatalysts [13–15]. Thus, it is significant to accelerate the kinetics of mass and electric transfer for electrode [16]. Typically, the electrocatalytic reactions occur at the liquid/solid or gas/liquid/solid interface, and the wettability represents the distribution state of gas and liquid on the solid electrode surface [17]. Thus, tuning the wettability of electrode directly affects the gas bubbles’ behavior underwater, influencing the mass transfer of electrocatalytic interface [18,19]. In addition, an efficient mass transfer of electrocatalysts is important in industrial conditions, especially under the large current density condition where the wettability of electrode surface is the rate-determining factor [20]. Therefore, the application of wettability control in electrocatalysis is emerging as a novel researching hotspot with great potential [21]. Inspired by nature, researchers have summarized the laws of solid surface structure influencing liquid state and further applied in sensors [22], water collection [23], self-cleaning [24], oil/water separation [25], and anti-bioadhesion [26], etc. Similarly, the wettability control is also widely applied in electrocatalysis. The design of electrocatalysts with tunable wettability is in two views of microstructure and system. As for the microstructure design, various strategies, including surface coating, morphology control, and functional group modification, have been applied to construct micro artificial interface with desirable wettability. Surface coating means that using ideal chemical compositions (e.g., hydrophilic/hydrophobic polymer) to modify the surface in order to change the wettability. Morphology control indicates that constructing the specific surface with a high roughness (well-order nanoarrays, nanorods, etc.) can promote the intrinsic wettability of electrode materials (hydrophilic to superhydrophilic, hydrophobic to superhydrophobic). For the materials with difficulty to control their morphology, modifying hydrophilic/hydrophobic functional groups is an available strategy. Besides, system design of macro-view device can utilize the intrinsic wettability of electrode to tune the distribution of liquid and gas on the reaction interfaces [27]. For example, the wettability modification on gas diffusion electrode (GDE) is of great importance in fuel cells and rechargeable metal-air batteries [28]. In this review, we firstly review the basic theories of wettability and the mechanisms of wettability applications to electrocatalysis. Subsequently, the recent methods of wettability modification in electrocatalytic microstructure and system are summarized for reference. Furthermore, the existing problems and future development of wettability modification are discussed and prospected. This review aims to provide the latest works and methods from micro and macro views to provide inspiration and ideas for electrocatalysis researches. 2 Basic theory Electrocatalytic reactions are generally occurring on the multi-phase interface. Wettability can describe the balance of gas–liquid-solid on the electrode surface. Thus, the wettability of the electrode surface is a non-negligible property that affects the electrocatalytic performance. In 1804, Thomas Young firstly proposed the concept of contact angle (CA), which is the angle between the solid/liquid interface and liquid/gas interface through the liquid phase when a liquid–vapor interface meets a solid surface [29]. The CA can quantify the degree of wettability for a liquid on a surface via Young’s equation, showing as follows [30]: (1) γ S V = γ S L + γ L V c o s θ where γ S V , γ S L and γ L V represent the interfacial tension of solid/gas, solid/liquid, and liquid/gas, respectively, and θ is the intrinsic CA of the liquid [19]. Fig. 1 (a) shows the schematic diagram of the CA. Generally, the hydrophilic surface is the one where the CA of aqueous solution is lower than 90°, in contrast, the hydrophobic surface is the one where the CA of aqueous solution is higher than 90°. Moreover, when a surface performs the apparent CA of aqueous solution below 10° or higher than 150°, it is superhydrophilic or superhydrophobic [31]. Theoretically, the chemical and physical conditions of materials are major factors to influence the wettability on surface [21,24,32,33]. Among them, the chemical composition has been regarded as the determiner to decide the surface energy, which relates to the wettable character (hydrophobicity or hydrophilicity). For example, the metal and glass often possess hydrophilicity for high surface energy. The rubber and Poly tetra fluoroethylene (PTFE) have hydrophobicity for low surface energy [34]. Usually, Young’s equation is applicable in an ideal surface (homogeneous, smooth, invariant, and isotropic), it cannot give a reliable result in a real surface. Given this challenge, Wenzel, Cassie, Baxter, etc. studied the static and dynamic behaviors of the liquid on the real solid surfaces in detail, such as rough surface, heterogeneous surface, additionally they have revealed the phenomenon for the hysteresis of CA [35–40]. Therefore, researchers have proposed three models to describe the wetting condition of a liquid on a rough surface, called Wenzel state, Cassie-Baxter state, and Wenzel-Cassie coexistent state, respectively [41]. In a hydrophilic rough solid surface, Wenzel modified Young’s equation to obtain the apparent CA ( θ W ∗ ) of liquid by introducing a roughness factor r, which represents the ratio of the actual surface area to geometric surface area [35]. The relationship of the apparent CA and the intrinsic CA is described by the Wenzel equation: (2) c o s θ W ∗ = r c o s θ The liquid with the θ W ∗ is called in Wenzel state (Fig. 1b). Obviously, the rougher surface is easier to wet. However, when the intrinsic CA is too large, the surface becomes hydrophobic, and liquid does not fill the grooves of rough surface and leaves gas gaps, the Wenzel equation is unavailable. In this situation, the liquid only contacts with the top of surface bulges. So that, Cassie and Baxter built a relationship between the apparent CA ( θ C B ∗ ) and the real contact area ( f s ) [37], shown as follows: (3) c o s θ C B ∗ = f s c o s θ + 1 - 1 The liquid with the θ C B ∗ is called in Cassie-Baxter state (Fig. 1c). Then, Cassie expended this result for a chemically heterogeneous surface, which is called Cassie’s law [43]: c o s θ C ∗ = ∑ i = 1 n x i c o s θ i , ∑ i = 1 n x i = 1 where θ i is the CA of component i with surface fraction x i . Besides, Wenzel-Cassie coexistent state (Fig. 1d) is a transition state between Wenzel state and Cassie-Baxter state [21]. Thus, the surface morphology, as the accelerator, promotes the degree of hydrophobicity or hydrophilicity [44]. The intrinsic wetting threshold (IWT) of a material determines how the roughness of surface affects wettability [21,45]. When the apparent CA of a material surface is greater than the θ IWT on a flat surface, the hydrophobicity can be enhanced by increasing the roughness. In contrast, the hydrophilicity will enhance as the roughness increases if the apparent CA is less than the θ IWT, the hydrophilicity will increase as the roughness increases [32]. Recently, more and more studies demonstrated the significance of wettability for electrocatalysis and proposed new mechanisms of wettability controlling electrocatalytic reactions [20,46–48]. The equation describes the factors of electrode polarizing current for an electrochemical reaction is shown as follows [49]: (4) i l i m i t i n g = zFD δ C ∗ where z is the number of electrons transferred in the reaction, F is Faraday constant, D is diffusion coefficient, C ∗ is the concentration of the electroactive species in the bulk electrolyte and δ represents diffusion layer thickness. The current density i l i m i t i n g is inversely proportional to the diffusion layer thickness. For the gas evolution reactions (GERs), the reactions occur at the liquid/solid di-phase interface, whereas the gas products hinder the contact between the electrode and electrolyte. Hence, the thickness of the gas adhering to the catalyst interface can be regarded as the diffusion thickness. As the thickness of the adhering gas decreases, the current density will increase with the thinner diffusion layer. The wettability of electrocatalyst could greatly affect the adhering of gas bubble and thus determines the diffusion layer thickness [47]. Normally, superhydrophilic electrodes are designed for accelerating the reaction rate towards GERs [50–52]. For the gas consumption reactions (GCRs), the reactions occur at the gas/liquid/solid tri-phase interface, the gas phase and liquid phase are both the reactants, thus, the diffusion thickness is the distance of the gas reactants diffusing from bulk electrolyte to catalytic sites. Tuning wettability of electrode can adjust the transfer efficiency of the gas reactants, further affecting the current density and selectivity of GCRs [53]. Normally, on the surface of electrodes, the effect of gas/liquid dynamic balance is different towards different electrocatalysts. Thus, some GCRs require superhydrophobic electrodes [54–56], and others need moderate hydrophobic electrodes [42]. 3 Methods of wettability modification Since the wettability inevitable influences diffusion thickness between reactants and reaction interface, wettability modification have attracted massive attention in the common field of electrocatalysis such as oxygen evolution reaction (OER), hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), and carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR) [57]. Numerous works tried to fabricate a reaction surface with reliable wettability from micro perspective and achieved the purpose of improving electrocatalytic efficiency and selectivity [53]. Meanwhile, a multi-level macroscopic of wettability design is also successively applied in electrocatalytic systems such as the GDE of rechargeable zinc-air batteries (ZABs). Therefore, this chapter summarizes the methods of wettability modification from microstructure design and macro-level system design. 3.1 Microstructure design As for the electrocatalysis, an ideal electrocatalyst surface should possess high porosity and high conductivity to keep the efficient processes of mass transfer and electric conductivity. Therefore, the structure design of electrode needs to reduce the adhesion of gas bubbles for GERs (such as OER and HER) [46], and provide an effective path for gas diffusion for GCRs (such as ORR and CO2RR) [56]. According to the two main characteristics (surface chemical composition and morphology) that affect surface wetting, three main methods are applied to modify the wettability of electrocatalyst, including surface coating, structural modification, and surface functionalization. 3.1.1 Surface coating The surface coating has been extensively applied in modifying the wettability of surface in early years [58]. The surface energy can be directly tuned by coating controllable chemical compositions. The wettability of the modified surface is finally decided by the involved species. For instance, hydrophilic polymers, including polyacrylic acid (PAA), polyethylene glycol (PEG) and polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP), and hydrophobic polymers, including poly tetra fluoroethylene (PTFE), poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF), polyethylene (PE), etc. are widely used in designing electrocatalysts with desirable wettability. For OER or ORR reactions, Zhang et al. [59] designed a multifunctional OER/ORR electrode by coating hydrophilic/hydrophobic polymers on the surface of super-absorbed nitrogen-doped graphene monomer on demand. The liquid/solid di-phase interface or the gas/liquid/solid tri-phase interface significantly promoted the GERs or GCRs, respectively (Fig. 2 a and b). Lv et al. [60] used a one-pot hydrothermal method to directly introduce highly hydrophilic PVP into Ni-Fe diselenide hollow nanoparticles (Fig. 2c). The CA measurements show that PVP improves the hydrophilicity of NiFe diselenide (Fig. 2d). The lactam group with strong polarity in PVP can interact with polar H2O molecules, which facilitate the adsorption/transfer efficiency of the ion species and eventually accelerate the kinetics of OER. Besides, the synthesis of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) through ORR or OER is a green substitute for anthraquinone compounds. Many researches have proved that a suitable surface wettability design for ORR is beneficial to increase the energy barrier of O2 to H2O and realize the high selectivity of H2O2 [61–65]. Recently, Zhang et al. [66] fabricated a natural air diffusion electrode (NADE), which allows air to diffuse naturally to the ORR interface without additional O2 input. This electrode effectively improves the production efficiency of H2O2 and the degradation efficiency of organic pollutants (Fig. 2e). They used carbon felt (CF) as the substrate and diffusion layer, and adjusted the hydrophobicity of the electrocatalytic layer by coating PTFE. The NADE not only simplifies the manufacturing process of ordinary gas diffusion electrodes but also establishes a stable superhydrophobic tri-phase interface. Xia et al. [55] reported an interface engineering method that regulates the OER pathway by coating a hydrophobic PTFE polymer on the carbon catalyst to reduce the generation of O2 in situ, promoting the selectivity and activity of the inherent H2O-to-H2O2. The maximum Faraday efficiency of H2O2 reached up to 66% at the overpotential of 640 mV. As for HER, many non-metallic materials, such as carbon and conductive polymers of which certain surface modification, are required to improve hydrophilicity. Based on this, Feng et al. [67] synthesized silica nanodots (SiO2 NDs) modified by polypyrrole nanotube composites (SiO2/PPyNTs-CFs), which were used as an advanced HER electrocatalyst in neutral system. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations, and Fourier transform IR spectra (FTIR) prove that PPyNTs-modified SiO2 NDs can effectively improve the absorption of water confirmed by the CA measurement, due to the hydrophilic properties of SiO2 NDs. As shown in Fig. 2(f), the strong electronic interaction between SiO2 NDs and PPy endows negative charges for SiO2, which can promote the activation of water molecules and electrons transfer. Jeon et al. [68], inspired by nature, deposited a superhydrophilic transparent hydrogel from M13 virus onto electrode for HER. The porous hydrophilic hydrogel was modified on the electrode surface, which contributes to lower the overpotential and eliminate the bubbles, thus reducing the coverage of active sites by bubbles. As for CO2RR, transition metal and metal-based materials are highly active electrocatalysts. However, metals generally have higher surface energy and tend to form hydrophilic surfaces, so they are necessary to coat the hydrophobic species (especially PTFE) for building hydrophobic surfaces, which keep a high proportion of gas on the reaction interface. Shi et al. [69] made use of a typical Au/C electrode as a model to investigate the effect of wettability on CO2RR. The researchers modified the gas/liquid/solid interface on the Au/C electrode with a superhydrophobic fluorine-terminated silane coupling agent (1,1,2,2-perfluorodecyltrimethoxysilane). The confocal laser scanning microscopy measurement showed that the Cassie-Wenzel coexistence state was ideal tri-phase reaction interface, which can continuously supply CO2 for active sites at high current density. Hydrophobic design except can inhibit the HER, also can tune the product selectivity of CO2RR. Liang et al. [70] designed a superhydrophobic electrode by coating PVDF on CuO electrode, as shown in Fig. 3 (a and b). The superhydrophobic character limits the electrolyte diffusing to the reaction interface. During the CO2RR, with the proton consumption, the remained OH− ions can enhance the local alkalinity, which benefits the C–C coupling to produce more ethylene. Cai et al. [71] modified the tri-phase reaction interface of the Cu nano-array electrode with PTFE, which changed the electrode surface from aerophobic to aerophilic. This treatment promotes the adsorption of CO2 and restricts the supply of protons, thereby increasing the production of hydrogen-depleted C1 (e.g., CO/HCOOH) and inhibiting HER (Fig. 3c and d). In short, the surface coating has been regarded as an efficient strategy to improve the product selectivity of CO2RR electrocatalysts, not only for inhibiting HER. Although surface coating has been widely utilized in the electrocatalysis field to modify the wettability of the electrodes, several disadvantages are not neglected [72,73]. For example, the coating species are often inert and may block the electrocatalytic sites which extremely weaken the activity of electrocatalyst. And then, the directly coated composition lacks of strong chemical bond with the substrate, causing low durability and stability. 3.1.2 Morphology control To avoid the disadvantages of surface coating, researchers modify the surface wettability by enhancing roughness and designing special nano-micro structure. For GERs, the surface of the electrocatalyst is often covered by generated gas bubbles which reduce the mass transfer and block the active sites [46]. In previous studies, a rotating electrode was usually used to drive off the gas bubbles, however, which is not available in industrial applications [74]. Therefore, a hydrophilic and gas-repellent electrode is expected to be constructed to reduce the adhesion of the gas bubble, releasing the small-sized gas bubbles, and exposing more active sites. Given this challenge, Lu et al. [75] first developed superaerophobic nano-porous architecture MoS2 via hydrothermal method (Fig. 4 a and b), which can cut the tri-phase contact line (TPCL) of gas bubbles and electrode surface into discontinuous state. Therefore, the contact area and adhesion between the gas bubble and solid electrode are reduced (Fig. 4c), the bubbles leave the surface easily, improving the HER performance of the electrode. After, Li et al. [11] studied the effect of different morphologies of Pt electrodes on HER performance. The researchers found that the pine-shaped Pt nanostructure electrode has ultra-low CA, compared with the Pt flat films. During the HER process, pine-shaped Pt nanostructure electrode produces the smallest gas bubbles (Fig. 4d) with the best HER performances. These phenomena are attributed to the array structure and ultra-high roughness of the pine-shaped Pt nanostructure, which facilitate the rapid release of H2 bubbles. The same theory is most widely applied in OER [76–79] and overall water splitting [80–85]. Shan et al. [86] synthesized a layered CoMoS x on nickel foam (CoMoS x /NF) by in-situ metathesis reaction. As shown in Fig. 4(e), the pleated multi-level micro-nano structure of the electrocatalyst brings the superhydrophilic property, significantly promotes the permeation of the electrolyte, leading to fast diffusion of water molecules. Meanwhile, this superhydrophilic surface can accelerate the desorption of gas bubbles, thereby enhancing the high-efficiency OER under large current density. In addition, similar results could also be observed in GERs such as chlorine evolution reaction (ClER) [87], hydrazine oxidation reaction (HzOR) [88], and wet air oxidation [89]. For GCRs, the gas reactants need to diffuse to the electrode. However, the limited solubility in aqueous seriously restricts the mass transfer efficiency of the gas reactants. As for CO2RR, one of typical GCRs, the reaction current density is too low for industrial application in the H-cell. The weak mass transfer greatly limits the efficiency of CO2RR [90]. Given this challenge, inspired by Setaria’s leaves, Niu et al. [91] developed a hydrophobic copper electrode, performing a high-curvature hierarchical tip structure. This electrode can effectively prevent the immersion by electrolyte, meanwhile, vast needle tip structure further enhanced the interfacial electric field, stabilized the reaction intermediates, and promoted C–C coupling. Therefore, compared with particulate copper electrodes, dendritic copper electrodes exhibit higher multi-carbon product Faraday efficiency, partial current density, and excellent stability. When the hydrophobicity of dendritic copper electrode was destroyed by air plasma irradiation, the stability of it rapidly decreased. This fact reveals the hydrophobicity of electrode is the key factor for stability. Likewise, the wettability of the electrodes also plays an important role in catalyzing the ORR process. As shown in Fig. 4(f), Wang et al. [42] designed three platinum-plated samples with different conductive columnar structures and water CAs of the three samples and investigated their effect on the ORR performance of the electrodes. By chemical modified with 1H,1H,2H,2H-perfluorodecyltrime-thoxysilane for enhancing hydrophobicity, the θ IWT is small than the apparent CA of the samples’ surface and the hydrophobicity gradually increased with the roughness increased due to smaller silicon pillars’ size. Sample III has the strongest hydrophobicity and gas absorption capacity, which is generally considered to be a favorable factor for GCRs. However, the ORR catalytic performance was the worst in sample III (Fig. 4f). It is worth noting that sample II has a balanced adhesion to water and gas, and the ORR catalytic performance is the highest. Therefore, the adsorption capacity of the material surface to the equilibrium of liquid and gas to maximum gas/liquid/solid contact area is very important for the tri-phase interface reaction. This research provided theoretical guidance for structural modification in GCRs. In summary, the logical structure design of electrodes with different wettability states can effectively improve the mass transfer efficiency of reactants. The morphology control is expected to show more potential in controlling underwater gas bubble behavior to achieve the purpose of industrial application. 3.1.3 Functional group modification Surface functionalization is a method with more universal, compared to morphology control. Modifying functional groups can control the surface energy of a solid surface to realize the wettability tuning, and also introduce new physical and chemical properties [92,93]. Inspired by this, Dastafkan et al. [94] took advantage of borate to functionalize Fe/NF electrodes. The functionalized surface with borate has high hydrophilicity, which reduces the surface tension between the Fe sites and the electrolyte, and decreases the adhesion of gas bubbles. The modified surface results in rapid desorption of gas bubbles and adsorption of water and intermediates, which greatly enhances the OER performance. Besides, numerous studies have reported that a CV pre-treatment is usually applied before the electrochemical tests of OER [95–98]. This treatment can graft hydrophilic groups (–OH, –OOH, etc.) on the surface of catalysts, which enhances the hydrophilicity of the surface for promoting the OER performances [10]. In a word, grafting chemical groups endows the electrocatalyst surface with rational wettability and special chemical natures. This strategy is widely applied in other catalysis. For example, the hydrophobic Cu/ZnO catalyst by surface-modifying the stearic acid molecules can improve the selectivity of producing dimethyl ether from syngas (CO + H2), and suppress the competing water–gas shift reaction [99]. However, in electrocatalysis, minor works are about using functional group modification for tuning wettability. Therefore, as for the electrocatalysis focused on the production selectivity (CO2RR, H2O2 production), functional group modification maybe a good strategy for selectivity tuning. 3.1.4 Multi-strategy Above modification methods all possess unique advantages, and they are no conflict between each other. Thus, many works combine various methods for tuning the wettability of the electrode surface. Li et al. [100] developed a hydrophilic electrocatalyst (NiFe/NiFe:Pi) composed of iron hydroxide and ferrous phosphate through constructing a nanosheet structure and introducing phosphoric acid groups (Fig. 5 a), which shows excellent water oxidation performance. What’s more, Li et al. [101] employed PTFE to partially modify the aerophobic nitrogen-doped carbon nanotube arrays and prepared a Janus electrode with asymmetric wettability as a high-performance electrode for ORR. The Janus electrode with opposite wettability on the adjacent side maintained a stable gas storage layer on the aerophilic side and shortened the O2 channel on the aerophobic side. Cu dendrite is one of the efficient catalysts towards electrocatalytic CO2RR. As shown in Fig. 5(b), Wakerley et al. [102] studied how the wettability of Cu dendrite electrode tunes the selectivity in CO2RR. Inspired by the structure of the spider’s stratum corneum, the researchers used physical methods to prepare Cu dendritic array with high roughness. Then, the Cu dendritic array was treated with 1-octadecanethiol to successfully construct superhydrophobic surface. Under neutral pH conditions, the Faraday efficiency of ethylene and ethanol were 56% and 17% respectively on the superhydrophobic electrode. In contrast, the Faraday efficiencies were only 9% and 4% on the hydrophilic electrode, respectively. After wettability optimization, the concentration of CO2 at the interface of the electrode was obviously raised, improving the selectivity of CO2RR. de Arquer et al. [103] proposed a hybrid wettability catalyst design for CO2RR. The researchers designed a three-dimensional ionomer bulk heterojunction to assemble into morphological differentiation. Specifically, gas passed through the hydrophobic area of the side chain to improve the transport efficiency and prolonged gas diffusion on the metal surface, while ion transport and water absorption occurred in the hydrophilic area. As a result, the tri-phase reaction interface has greatly expanded, and the mass transfer range has increased from submicron to several microns in length (Fig. 5c). By decoupling gas, ion, and electron transport, the catalyst could efficiently catalyze CO2 and CO to produce multi-carbon products at a current density of more than 1 A cm−2. In brief, the gas diffusion pathway could be enormously expanded by manufacturing the electrode to desired wettability. Many interesting and extraordinary catalysts by structural design as well as surface coating have been explored to open new horizons for future research. 3.2 System design The above strategies towards electrocatalysts proved the improvements of wettability controlling for GERs and GCRs. Therefore, it is feasible to extend these strategies to macro-scale electrocatalytic systems. Wettability controlling of energy devices can control bubbles and electrolyte transport channels in the macro-scale, performing a high potential in practical application. 3.2.1 Electrode design Recently, some novel structural architectures have been proposed in electrode design, structures controlling, and chemical states tuning to adjust the diffusion pathway of gas and liquid. Specially, the structure design of the self-support electrode can modify the gas diffusion layer (GDL) in situ to control the tri-phase interface reaction. The production of ethylene on the Cu electrocatalyst under the alkaline reaction conditions is hindered by the competitive reaction of bicarbonate generation. Dinh et al. [104] considered that the instability of Cu on carbon-based GDE was due to the loss of hydrophobicity during CO2RR. The pathway of CO2 diffusion to the electrocatalyst will be impeded in a hydrophilic surface. Thus, they designed a sandwich-type electrode, the catalysts layer caught between the hydrophobic layer and conductive carriers, which can withstand alkali by optimizing the diffusion of CO2 to the catalytic active site. This novel structure of GDE maintains a high ethylene selectivity during long-term electrolysis. Yang et al. [105] fabricated a porous carbon membrane with single-atom Ni-doped, which integrated the GDL and catalyst layer. Benefitting from interconnected nanofibers and hierarchical pores, this high-yield, flexible and self-supported membrane can provide a desirable tri-phase interface for CO2RR. In the conventional rechargeable ZAB cathode, the (2D) two-dimensional multi-phase interface of the GDL inevitably leads to insufficient active sites and poor interface contact, resulting in slow reaction kinetics [106]. Yu et al. [107] proposed a 3D multi-phase strategy to extend the reaction interface into the GDL. They designed a Janus carbon fiber paper with a hydrophilic/hydrophobic surface, which was prepared by precise control of single-sided pretreatment. The expansion of the 2D to 3D contact interface of asymmetric air cathode leads to increased active sites, accelerating mass transfer and a dynamically stable reaction interface (Fig. 6 a). The ZAB based on asymmetric cathodes possesses a small charge–discharge voltage gap (0.81 V at 5.0 mA cm−2) and stable cycle performance (more than 2000 times). As for OER, Hu et al. [108] synthesized a conductive hydrogel of superhydrophilic phytic acid to construct a highly efficient OER electrocatalyst. The author immobilized PA molecules in a porous polypyrrole (PPy) network. The formed hydrogel has a super-hydrophilic surface, which can promote the contact between the electrolyte and electrocatalyst, thereby accelerating the mass transfer during OER. 3.2.2 Device design Currently, some studies applied surface wettability engineering to design energy conversion devices, which optimize the tri-phase interface and lead to more efficient mass transfer. For instance, Long et al. [109] fabricated a water splitting device utilizing Janus asymmetric electrode to achieve effective 3D bubble transport. As shown in Fig. 6(b), the wettability gradient of the Janus electrode is changed by coating polydimethylsiloxane on a single surface to promote the vertical penetration of bubbles. Besides, the spontaneous surface transport in the horizontal direction from the geometric gradient is promoted by cutting the material into triangle. Afterward, a novel integral water splitting device with two multi-electrode arrays was constructed, which completes the integration of gas bubble generation, directional transportation, and pure collection. The distance between cathode and anode can be reduced to 1 mm, and the corresponding current density is 1.5 times higher than that under normal conditions. As for CO2RR, the current density in high-pH electrolytes is higher than that in near-neutral pH electrolytes, but the high-concentration solution inevitably reacts with CO2, so a constant flow of high-concentration electrolyte is needed to compensate for the reaction loss [110]. Inspired by the exchange of O2 and CO2 in alveoli and capillaries during the human breath, Li et al. [111] developed a double-pocket artificial alveolar structure, which was composed of a highly flexible ultra-thin nano porous polyethylene (NanoPE) film and a very thin layer of Au. The hydrophobicity of nano-polyethylene leads the artificial alveolar structure to provide vast active sites at the tri-phase interface and achieved local pH adjustment in the interlayer of the bilayer membranes. As a result, the electrochemical CO2RR at − 0.6 V (vs. RHE) achieved an excellent CO generation Faraday efficiency (FECO) of ∼ 92% and current density of ∼ 25.5 mA cm−2. In summary, the efforts on wettability control on macro-view are still limited and need further research. For instance, the Janus electrode or device with non-uniform wettability has great potential in future applications. Additionally, the concept could be extended to other worthy electrocatalysis systems (chlorine evolution reaction, nitrogen reduction reaction, hydrazine oxidation reaction, etc.). Besides, wettability control has a wide range of applications in many energy conversion devices, such as lithium-ion batteries [112–114], lithium-sulfur batteries [115], supercapacitors [116], flow cell [117], fuel cells [118], solar-powered water evaporation [119], photoelectric synthesis of ammonia [120], dehydrogenation coupling of organosilane [121], electrochemical biosensor [122], etc. Table 1 summarizes the recent research progresses of wettability control in electrocatalysis. Briefly, it can be found that the commonly used electrocatalytic materials are transition metal/metal compounds, perovskites, and carbon-based materials. For the OER, representative materials include NiFe-based materials, and for HER, they are Ni-based or Pt-based materials. These metal/metal compounds tend to have higher surface energy with the better intrinsic hydrophilicity better. Their hydrophilicity will increase as the roughness increases. Therefore, for GERs, metal/metal compounds often use strategies of increasing surface roughness, building micro-nano structures, and introducing hydrophilic groups to alter wettability. For GCRs such as CO2RR and ORR, metal/metal compounds such as Cu, Au and Pt are often used. However, in order to improve the hydrophobicity of these metal-based materials, researchers often apply surface coating method to reduce the intrinsic hydrophilicity of the surface and then modify the structure to further enhance the hydrophobicity. For carbon-based materials, their intrinsic hydrophilicity is often limited, so it is recommended to introduce hydrophilic groups to improve their hydrophilicity. 4 Summary and outlook This review briefly introduces recent works on controlling interface wettability from the perspective of micro and macro views, as well as various methods of modification, such as morphology control, introducing hydrophilic groups and surface coating. In general, surface wettability is of great significance for the design and development of heterogeneous electrocatalysts. For different energy conversion systems, the high hydrophilic/hydrophobic surfaces of the electrocatalyst surface have different design principles. For GERs, the design of electrodes with suitable wettability could reduce the adhesion of bubbles, thereby quickly releasing bubbles and expanding the solid–liquid contact area, that is, the catalytic activity area. In contrast, fabricating hydrophobic electrodes to expand the tri-phase interface can effectively improve the electron and ion transport efficiency for GCRs. By reasonably adjusting the surface structure and chemical properties, an ideal ion conductive phase, gas transport phase, and solid catalyst can be combined into a tri-phase boundary, which ensures the effective progress of the charge transfer, electrocatalytic efficiency and selectivity. This review only includes the studies in energy conversion and storage systems. However, the wettability technology has applications in a wide range of fields and shows great potential. In fact, wettability control is a cross-disciplinary subject technology. Although great research progress has been made in improving the intrinsic activity of catalysis, the works on wettability modification are still very limited. There are still some difficulties and challenges that need to be overcome. Herein, we propose several challenges and corresponding suggestions for the development of wettability modification in the future. (1) Using surface wettability modification to modulate product selectivity in multi-product electrocatalysis. The wettability of the electrode is closely related to the phase distribution and carrier distribution at the electrocatalytic reaction interface, which controls the product selectivity by regulating the reaction path. Such as CO2RR, most recent studies have mainly focused on HER inhibition by wettability modification, whereas only a few studies have controlled the other products selectivity by wettability modification. (2) The universality of interface wettability engineering needs further proof. Wettability control is currently only applied in a very limited number of electrocatalytic fields. It should be extended more to other fields such as methanol oxidation, nitrogen reduction reaction, hydrazine oxidation reaction, and chlorine evolution reaction which suffer from limited di- or tri-phase reaction interface. (3) The methods of wettability modification need to be boosted. For typical methods, structural modification is often restricted, because the specifically chemical property of different materials disallows to design the surface morphology arbitrarily. Surface coating usually causes coverage of active sites of electrocatalyst and unstable tri-phase interface. Up till now, some advanced wettability modification methods, such as 3D printing, plasma treatment, and ultraviolet radiation, can precisely design the surface with desirable wettability. For instance, the 3D printing can achieve specific micro morphology of materials and plasma treatment is able to etch the surface to alter the roughness of electrode. Moreover, the hydrophobic functional group can be generated by ultraviolet radiation. (4) The characterization technologies of surface wettability are limited. Nowadays, the most common technologies are the contact angle and adhesion measurements. However, they only provide the macro-level results, which cannot provide valuable evidence for understanding the micro-level mechanism of the wettability modifications. Thus, developing advanced characterization technologies (confocal laser scanning microscopy, environmental scanning electron microscope, high speed camera, etc. [69,147,148]) benefits to deeply comprehend the micro-level characters of surface wettability and the dynamic changes of interface wettability during the reaction process. In addition, theoretical calculations can also provide a new perspective for essentially optimizing the usage of wettability control in electrocatalysis. In summary, the rational design of electrodes with different wettability is a promising strategy to promote the practical industrial application of experimental catalysts. However, how to balance the relationship between electrocatalytic performance and the wettability requires further research. Yan Liang is currently pursuing his M.E. degree under the supervision of Prof. Jun Wang in the Key Laboratory of Solar Energy Science and Technology in Jiangsu Province at Southeast University. He received his B.S. degree from Southeast University in 2019. His research interests focus on the electrocatalysts based on metallic materials. Yifeng Han is currently a senior engineer of Power China Huadong Engineering Corporation Limited. He received his B.S. degree from Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics. His research interests focus on the design of renewable energy device and system. Jing-Sha Li joined in the Institute of Materials Science and Devices, Suzhou University of Science and Technology, in July, 2019. She received her PhD degree in June, 2019 from Central South University (China). Her current research is mainly focused on the chemical synthesis of nanomaterials for high-performance batteries, especially metal-air batteries and electrocatalysis. Jun Wang obtained his Ph.D. degree from Nanjing Tech University in 2005. He is currently a Professor in Southeast University and the deputy director of Key Laboratory of Solar Energy Science and Technology in Jiangsu Province. His main research interests are solar thermal utilization technology, electrocatalytic materials and energy storage materials. He has published more than 100 research articles in these fields. Depei Liu is a Ph.D. candidate in the School of Physics at Nanjing University, China. He received his B.S. and M.S. degree from College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering at Central South University, China in 2016 and 2019. His research interests focus on electrochemical water splitting and metal-air battery, including catalyst development and device application. Qi Fan obtained his Ph.D. degree from Nanjing University in 2012. He is currently a Professor of Key Laboratory of Solar Energy Science and Technology in Jiangsu Province at Southeast University. His research interests focus on future and advanced energy materials and advanced energy transition materials.

coredata.dc:description: Electrocatalysis, as a typical heterogeneous catalysis, generally occurs in the di- or tri-phase interfaces. Wettability is an important property for describing the balance of a gas-liquid-solid system. Therefore, the wettability of reaction interface, especially hydrophilicity/hydrophobicity, plays an important role in the adsorption/desorption process of gas bubbles on the surface of the solid electrode. Herein, we present a comprehensive review of the wettability control of the electrode materials applied in electrocatalysis reactions, including hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen evolution reaction (OER), oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR). Firstly, the basic theories of wettability as well as the impact on electrocatalysis were introduced in this review. Secondly, the overview of modifying methods of the wettability from electrocatalyst microstructure (structural modification, surface coating, introducing hydrophilic groups) and system design (electrode, device) were suggested. At last, the deficiencies and problems in the application of wettability control are discussed, and deeper and broader application prospects are proposed.
